channel.title: Do You Know Java?
channel.description: If you think you know a tiny bit about Java, let me just prove you wrong with a few questions. Do not use Google for this; these are extremely easy questions if you have any knowledge at all of Java. Some questions can't be answered in two or three words, but they're still extremely easy. 1: Define "modifiers" 2: Give the name of "<<" 3: Give the name of ">>" 4: What does OOP stand for? 5: Define a native method. 6: Give an example of a loop. 7: Name all the primitive types. 8: Can null be the value of a primitive type? 9: Explain inheritance. 10: What does JNI stand for? 11: Give a context in which a ClassCastException would be thrown. 12: Explain the difference between the "extends" keyword and the "implements" keyword. 13: Explain how the final modifier affects a class or member. Bonus question: What number is included in every valid .class file?

Bonus question: Dont know

item.title: Do You Know Java?
item.dc:creator: @Mod_Andy Mod Andy
item.description:
@Mod_Andy wrote:

1: Define “modifiers” = A Method
2: Give the name of “<<” = Left Shift
3: Give the name of “>>” = Right Shift
4: What does OOP stand for? = object oriented programer
5: Define a native method. = Written in Java Scrip ?
6: Give an example of a loop. = Such as ( )
7: Name all the primitive types. = No Idea
8: Can null be the value of a primitive type? = Nop
9: Explain inheritance. = Forming a New Class
10: What does JNI stand for? = Java Native Interface
11: Give a context in which a ClassCastException would be thrown. = An Unknown Object
12: Explain the difference between the “extends” keyword and the “implements” keyword. = No Clue !
13: Explain how the final modifier affects a class or member. Dont Understand
Bonus question: What number is included in every valid .class file? I Dont Know … Guest of 8

Read full topic

item.title: Do You Know Java?
item.dc:creator: @swordskid61 Swordskid61
item.description:
@swordskid61 wrote:

1: Define “modifiers” - Basically how a class or method can be used.
2: Give the name of “<<” - left shift
3: Give the name of “>>” - right shift
4: What does OOP stand for? - object oriented programming
5: Define a native method. - Methods written in C code.
6: Give an example of a loop. - for ( ; ; ) or while(this) this
7: Name all the primitive types. - byte, short, int, long, float, double, boolean, char
8: Can null be the value of a primitive type? - yes
9: Explain inheritance. - Gives traits to the new class
10: What does JNI stand for? - java native interface
11: Give a context in which a ClassCastException would be thrown. - means that somewhere an object is trying to be cast to a type to which the object can not be casted.
12: Explain the difference between the “extends” keyword and the “implements” keyword. - extends allows a subclass to inherit traits from a main class, implements allows objects created to be used in anything that expects a value of the interface.
13: Explain how the final modifier affects a class or member. - cannot be overriden
i cheated ^(^_^)^
[center] Way to copy everyone here.[/center]

Read full topic

item.title: Do You Know Java?
item.dc:creator: @Sick_of_Air Sick of Air
item.description:
@Sick_of_Air wrote:

Rofl @ ownage plz

It’s true, not many people here can answer these questions, myself included, because PServer Java is relatively easy compared to actual Java. In some cases, I have seen other people say that PServer Java shouldn’t really be classified as Java, and I agree with them. Java really isn’t meant for 12 year olds and such to learn, but for the ones that do, congratulations ownage seems to be the only one here that can answer these questions, not including Silver, and I doubt many more people will be able to.

Read full topic

item.title: Do You Know Java?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Small note to other mods - don’t delete this topic.

1: Define “modifiers” - O man I don’t know.
2: Give the name of “<<” - Shift left
3: Give the name of “>>” - Shift right
4: What does OOP stand for? - Object Oriented Programming
5: Define a native method. - A native method would be a Java method whose implementation would be written in another language.
6: Give an example of a loop. - “while ( condition ) {”
7: Name all the primitive types. - byte, short, int, long, float, boolean, and finally, char.
8: Can null be the value of a primitive type? - No.
9: Explain inheritance. - Inheritance basically allows you to to inherit behaviour from another class, the superclass.
10: What does JNI stand for? - Java Native Interface
11: Give a context in which a ClassCastException would be thrown. - Where the code has tried to cast an object to a subclass which it is not an instance
12: Explain the difference between the “extends” keyword and the “implements” keyword. - Extends is used in an inheritance concept whereas implements is used in an interfaces concept.
13: Explain how the final modifier affects a class or member. - O man I don’t know.
Bonus question: What number is included in every valid .class file? - 8?

Read full topic

item.title: Do You Know Java?
item.dc:creator: @ownage_plz ownage plz
item.description:
@ownage_plz wrote:

1: Define “modifiers” - Basically how a class or method can be used.
2: Give the name of “<<” - left shift
3: Give the name of “>>” - right shift
4: What does OOP stand for? - object oriented programming
5: Define a native method. - Methods written in C code.
6: Give an example of a loop. - for ( ; ; ) or while(this) this
7: Name all the primitive types. - byte, short, int, long, float, double, boolean, char
8: Can null be the value of a primitive type? - no
9: Explain inheritance. - Gives traits to the new class
10: What does JNI stand for? - java native interface
11: Give a context in which a ClassCastException would be thrown. - means that somewhere an object is trying to be cast to a type to which the object can not be casted.
12: Explain the difference between the “extends” keyword and the “implements” keyword. - extends allows a subclass to inherit traits from a main class, implements allows objects created to be used in anything that expects a value of the interface.
13: Explain how the final modifier affects a class or member. - cannot be overridden

Read full topic

2: Give the name of “<<” Greater Than
3: Give the name of “>>” Less Than

6: Give an example of a loop. O
7: Name all the primitive types. Cavmen
8: Can null be the value of a primitive type? You can be anything if you put your mind to it.
9: Explain inheritance. A shit load of money you get when your parent die
10: What does JNI stand for? Joe nicked it.
11: Give a context in which a ClassCastException would be thrown. cast your rod into the classroom w/ exception of no bait.
12: Explain the difference between the “extends” keyword and the “implements” keywordtion. Thats an easy one, 2
13: Explain how the final modifier affects a class or member. Numbers, a Member is one person, a class is alota members
Bonus question: What number is included in every valid .class file? Sixty-nine?

item.title: Do You Know Java?
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

If you think you know a tiny bit about Java, let me just prove you wrong with a few questions. Do not use Google for this; these are extremely easy questions if you have any knowledge at all of Java. Some questions can’t be answered in two or three words, but they’re still extremely easy.
1: Define “modifiers”
2: Give the name of “<<”
3: Give the name of “>>”
4: What does OOP stand for?
5: Define a native method.
6: Give an example of a loop.
7: Name all the primitive types.
8: Can null be the value of a primitive type?
9: Explain inheritance.
10: What does JNI stand for?
11: Give a context in which a ClassCastException would be thrown.
12: Explain the difference between the “extends” keyword and the “implements” keyword.
13: Explain how the final modifier affects a class or member.
Bonus question: What number is included in every valid .class file?
